questions.text: Kaposi sarcoma present in Which CD4 count? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) <500

 

Kaposi's sarcoma is a common opportunistic infection associated with HIV infection. It typically presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells per cubic millimeter. Kaposi's sarcoma is a type of cancer that forms in the lining of blood and lymph vessels. The exact CD4 count at which Kaposi's sarcoma presents can vary, but it is generally observed in patients with moderately suppressed immune systems, which corresponds to a CD4 count of less than 500 cells/mm³.

 

Graph showing the Opportunistic infections associated with HIV infections and correlation with CD4 T cells counts.

 

 

When the CD4 count is at 500, individuals might also face bacterial skin infections, HSV, and fungal infections. As the CD4 count drops further, other infections like hairy leukoplakia and tuberculosis (at CD4 < 400), PCP, Cryptococcus, and Toxoplasmosis (at CD4 < 200), and infections like MAC, CMV, and lymphoma (at CD4 < 50) can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi's sarcoma in HIV patients generally presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells/mm³.

questions.text: Neonatal meningitis is caused by? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

Explanation:

 

Neonatal meningitis, which occurs in newborns up to 28 days old, can be caused by various pathogens. The most common cause of neonatal meningitis is Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS). This bacterium is a leading cause of both neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

 

Streptococcus agalactiae is a Group B beta-hemolytic streptococcus and is known for its positive CAMP test and Hippurate hydrolysis test. These tests help in the identification and confirmation of the bacteria.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Group A streptococci: Although Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) can cause various infections, it is not the primary cause of neonatal meningitis.

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: This bacterium is a common cause of meningitis in older children and young adults but is not the primary pathogen in neonatal meningitis.

 

Option D. H. influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae can cause meningitis in children, particularly those aged 2 months to 3 years, but it is not the most common cause in neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of neonatal meningitis is Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus).

 

MC Causes of Acute Pyogenic (bacterial) Meningitis

 

  • Neonates: Group B streptococcus (Str. agalactiae)
  • 2 months to 3 years: Pneumococci > Meningococci > H. influenzae
  • 3 years to 20 years: Meningococci
  • > 20 years: Pneumococci

 

Additional Information

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and myalgia after a tick bite. Laboratory investigation reveals characteristic inclusion bodies (morulae) within lymphocytes. Which organism is most likely responsible? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ehrlichia ewingii

 

Explanation: 

 

Ehrlichia ewingii causes human ewingii ehrlichiosis and characteristically forms morulae within lymphocytes. This distinguishes it from other rickettsial organisms that have different cell tropisms.

 

Key Features:

  • Transmitted by lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum)
  • Forms characteristic morulae in lymphocytes
  • Causes fever, headache, myalgia
  • Diagnosed by blood smear examination and PCR
  • Treatment: Doxycycline

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaplasma phagocytophilum: Incorrect. Forms morulae in neutrophils (granulocytes), not lymphocytes.

 

Option B. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Incorrect. Causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) and forms morulae in monocytes, not lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Neoehrlichia mikurensis: Incorrect. Recently discovered pathogen that primarily affects immunocompromised patients and does not form characteristic morulae.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand the cell tropism of different rickettsial organisms:

  • Anaplasma → neutrophils
  • E. chaffeensis → monocytes
  • E. ewingii → lymphocytes

questions.text: A 47-year-old renal transplant patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oval cysts 30 x 15 microns as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the causative organism:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isospora

 

In this case, the patient is a renal transplant recipient, indicating an immunocompromised state due to immunosuppressive drugs. Immunocompromised patients are more susceptible to infections, including parasitic infections causing diarrhea.

 

The stool examination revealed oval cysts measuring 30 x 15 microns, which were acid-fast positive. These characteristics are crucial in identifying the parasite:

 

  1. Immunocompromised State: This condition makes the patient more prone to infections by opportunistic parasites.
  2. Acid-Fast Positive Cysts: This staining characteristic is seen in certain parasitic cysts.
  3. Size and Shape of Cysts: The cysts are oval and measure 30 x 15 microns.

 

Based on the provided images and reference notes, Isospora belli (now known as Cystoisospora belli) is the parasite that fits these criteria. Isospora cysts are known to be oval in shape and measure approximately 20 to 30 microns in length, consistent with the 30 x 15 microns cysts described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium cysts are round, not oval, and are much smaller (4 to 6 microns). They do not fit the size and shape described in this case.

 

Option C. Cyclospora: Cyclospora cysts are also round and measure approximately 8 to 10 microns, which do not match the size and shape given in the question.

 

Option D. Microsporidia: Microsporidia produce very small spores (1 to 2 microns) and are not typically described as having 30 x 15 microns cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isospora belli (Cystoisospora belli) causes watery diarrhea in immunocompromised patients and is identified by its oval cysts measuring approximately 20 to 30 microns, which are acid-fast positive.

choices.text: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins
5-12 years is a high-risk group

questions.text: Which of the following is false about influenza? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5-12 years is a high-risk group

 

People at greater risk of severe disease or complications when infected are:

 

  1. pregnant women
  2. Children under 59 months
  3. Elderly
  4. Individuals with chronic medical conditions (such as chronic cardiac, pulmonary, renal, metabolic, neurodevelopmental, liver or hematologic diseases)
  5. Individuals with immunosuppressive conditions (such as HIV/AIDS, receiving chemotherapy or steroids, or malignancy).
  6. Health care workers are at high risk acquiring influenza virus infection due to increased exposure to the patients and risk further spread particularly to vulnerable individuals.

 

Mode of transmission – droplet infection

 

Incubation period – 1 to 4 days

 

Contagious period - About one day before developing any symptoms and up to seven days after the symptoms resolve.

 

Birds, especially aquatic birds act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza or bird flu refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR), defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (i.e., household or close contacts), can provide an indication of how social interactions relate to transmission risk. It is 5- 15% for influenza.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Virus shedding is present before symptoms begin: This is true. Influenza can be contagious before symptoms appear, which contributes to its rapid spread.

 

Option C. Aquatic birds act as a reservoir: This is true. Birds, especially aquatic birds, act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza, or bird flu, refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

Option D. Secondary attack rate is 5-15%: This is true. The secondary attack rate (SAR) for influenza, defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (e.g., household or close contacts), is typically between 5-15%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children under 5 years, pregnant women, the elderly, individuals with chronic medical conditions or immunosuppressive conditions, and health care workers are at greater risk of severe disease or complications from influenza. The 5-12 years age group is not specifically categorized as high-risk for severe disease from influenza.

questions.text: A patient recovered from Covid-19, treated with steroids, now presents with nasal discharge for 3 weeks. What does the histopathological image indicate? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Candida: Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.

 

Option D. Trichosporon: Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

 

  • The provided case involves an elderly man with meningitis, and the smear analysis indicates the presence of a gram-positive bacillus, strongly indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria exhibits motility at 25°C but loses its ability to move at 37°C.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES

 

  • Motility: shows differential motility, which is due to temperature dependent flagella expression) 
    • Tumbling type of motility at 25°C
    • Non-Motile at 37°C
  • Culture → Blood agar, Chocolate agar
  • Selective media → PALCAM agar

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Meningitis → DOC → Ampicillin in combination with gentamicin for synergistic effect
  • Penicillin allergy → Cotrimoxazole
  • In febrile gastroenteritis → Amoxicillin

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

questions.text: Colonies with bisected pearl appearance is seen in: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bordetella

 

Explanation: 

 

Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough, is characterized by colonies with a bisected pearl appearance. This appearance is distinctive and helps in the identification of the bacterium in laboratory settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycoplasma: Exhibits a "fried egg" appearance of colonies and is the smallest free-living bacteria.

 

Option B. Brucella: Does not show bisected pearl appearance; it grows as small, smooth colonies.

 

Option D. diphtheriae: Displays different colony appearances such as daisy head (gravis), frog egg (intermedius), or poached egg (mitis), but not bisected pearl appearance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bordetella pertussis colonies have a unique bisected pearl appearance.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

 

Rotavirus is among the most common identifiable viral causes of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years. Most cases are asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance.

 

Diagnosis – ELISA – Detects rotavirus antigen in Stool

 

  • Molecular methods – PCR, BioFilm Array

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antigen detection in blood: Not used for rotavirus as the virus does not typically present in blood.

 

Option C. Antibody detection in serum: This method is not typically used for acute diagnosis as it indicates past exposure rather than current infection.

 

Option D. Light microscopy of stool specimen: This is ineffective for viruses like rotavirus due to their small size and lack of distinctive morphology in light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigen detection in stool samples is the standard diagnostic approach for confirming rotavirus infection, crucial for implementing appropriate management strategies, especially in managing dehydration risks in young children.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute angled branching aspergillus

 

The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45°) uniform, branching septate hyphae which is suggestive of Aspergillus species.

 

Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear characteristic conidial structures. Long aseptate conidiophores are seen with terminal vesicles on which phialides are arranged in basipetal chains.

 

The following image shows LPCB mount of Aspergillus fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obtuse angled mucor: Mucor produces non-septate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium.

 

Option B. Acute angled penicillium: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like conidiophores.

 

Option D. Obtuse angled Rhizopus: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in groups directly above the rhizoids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain shows characteristic features of Aspergillus species. These features include acute-angled (45°) uniform branching septate hyphae.

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli are acid fast but non-branching

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae bacilli are less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus; therefore, 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

 

Option D. Actinomyces are gram-positive but non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

 

The following image shows the filamentous gram-positive stained actinomyces:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia can be identified by its branching filamentous structure on gram stain and weak acid-fast positivity due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall, distinguishing it from other gram-positive and acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and a gradual onset of fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, revealing an elevated opening pressure and a cerebrospinal fluid analysis, showing a positive India Ink stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis are:

The patient is HIV-positive, indicating an immunocompromised state.

The presentation of persistent headache, confusion, and gradual onset of fever is consistent with meningitis.

 

The lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, which is seen in meningitis.

The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows a positive India Ink stain, which is a negative stain used to detect capsulated organisms like Cryptococcus neoformans.


Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that commonly causes chronic meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

 

Indian Ink Preparation showing Cryptococcus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: While the symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are consistent with bacterial meningitis, the positive India Ink stain indicates the presence of a fungal organism rather than bacteria.

 

Option B. Viral encephalitis: The symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are not typically seen in viral encephalitis, which primarily affects the brain parenchyma rather than the meninges. Additionally, the positive India Ink stain is not consistent with a viral etiology.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Although tuberculous meningitis is a chronic form of meningitis, it is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a bacterium, and would not result in a positive India Ink stain, which is specific for detecting Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that can cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

A positive India Ink stain on CSF analysis, along with elevated opening pressure and compatible clinical symptoms, strongly suggests Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis.

questions.text: A confirmed case of which of the following viral hemorrhagic fevers was found in India? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Nairovirus species. This disease is zoonotic, meaning it originates from animals, with ticks acting as vectors.

 

Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF):

 

  • Causative Agent: Nairovirus species.
  • Transmission: The primary vectors are ticks, specifically those of the Hyalomma genus.
  • Outbreaks: The disease can spread through person-to-person transmission, particularly in healthcare settings, where it poses a significant risk to healthcare workers and patients.
  • Symptoms: Include fever, muscle pain, dizziness, neck pain and stiffness, backache, headache, sore eyes, and photophobia. Severe cases can lead to extensive hemorrhaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebola: Ebola is another severe viral hemorrhagic fever but has not been reported in India. It primarily affects regions in Africa.

 

Option B. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is a mosquito-borne viral hemorrhagic disease endemic to Africa and South America. It has not been reported in India.

 

Option D. Marburg: Marburg virus causes a severe hemorrhagic fever similar to Ebola. It has also not been reported in India and is primarily found in Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is the viral hemorrhagic fever that has been confirmed in India. It is caused by the Nairovirus species and is transmitted by ticks, with potential for person-to-person transmission, especially in healthcare settings.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

 

The Hemagglutination Test does not involve antibody marking. This test is used primarily to detect the agglutination of red blood cells (RBCs) by substances such as viruses or anti-blood group antibodies. The principle behind hemagglutination involves the ability of certain entities like viruses to bind directly to receptors on the surfaces of RBCs, causing them to clump together without the need for an antibody to be present as a marker.

 

It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses antibodies that are tagged with an enzyme to detect the presence of antigens or other antibodies in a sample through a colorimetric change.

 

Option B. Radioimmunoassay: Involves antibodies or antigens labeled with a radioactive isotope to measure the concentration of substances in the blood.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Utilizes antibodies labeled with fluorescent dyes to detect specific antigens in tissues or cells under a fluorescence microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Level D will show parasitic ova in formal ether sedimentation test.

 

 

The above image shows formal ether sedimentation technique.

 

Sedimentation techniques use solutions of lower specific gravity than the parasitic organisms, thus concentrating the latter in the sediment. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water. Their natural tendency to settle out in aqueous solutions can be accelerated by light centrifugation.

 

Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores, so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. Parasitic elements are sedimented at the bottom.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris.

 

Option B. B: This level is where the plug of debris is found after centrifugation.

 

Option C. C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formal ether sedimentation technique separates parasitic elements based on their specific gravity. Parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D.

questions.text: Which of the following is a dematiaceous fungus? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cladosporium

 

  • The dematiaceous (brown-pigment) fungi are a large and heterogenous group of molds that cause a wide range of diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.
  • Among the more important human pathogens are Alternaria species, Bipolaris species, Cladophialophora (Cladosporium) bantiana, Curvularia species, Exophiala species, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Madurella species, Phialophora species, Scedosporium prolificans, Scytalidium dimidiatum, and Wangiella dermatitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor species: Incorrect Mucor species are not dematiaceous fungi. They are non-pigmented (hyaline) fungi that cause mucormycosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
 

Option B. Aspergillus niger: Incorrect Aspergillus niger is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a black mold, but it does not belong to the group of dematiaceous fungi. It is a common cause of aspergillosis.
 

Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Incorrect Blastomyces dermatitidis is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a dimorphic fungus that causes blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cladosporium is a dematiaceous fungus, characterized by its dark pigmentation due to melanin in its cell walls, and it is associated with various diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.

questions.text: Match the following eggs to the organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. The Hymenolepis nana egg - The egg is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryopore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere.  The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

2. Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm)

 

Two types of eggs are passed by the worms: (1) fertilized and (2) unfertilized.

 

  1. The fertilized eggs, laid by females, inseminated by mating with a male, are embryonated and develop into the infective eggs (Figs 3A to C. .
  2. The unfertilized eggs, are laid by uninseminated female. These are nonembryonated and cannot become infective

 

Features of roundworm egg

 

 

 

3. The egg of Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) is:

 

Oval or elliptical, measuring 60 μm by 40 mcm.

 

Colorless, not bile stained.

 

Surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.

 

Floats in saturated salt solution.

 

When released by the worm in the intestine, the egg contains an unsegmented ovum.

 

During its passage down the intestine, the ovum develops. When passed in feces, the egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with four or eight blastomeres.

 

There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and the egg shell (Figs A and B).

 

 

4. The eggs of Taenia solium and Tania saginata are indistinguishable.

 

The egg is spherical, measuring 30-40 mcm diameter. lt has a thin hyaline embryonic membrane around it, which soon disappears after release. The inner embryophore is radially striated and is yellow brown due to bile staining. In the center is a fully-developed embryo (oncosphere) with three pairs of hooklets (hexacanth embryo). The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to humans, whereas the eggs of T. solium are infective to pigs and humans too.

questions.text: Vibrio cholerae binds with which receptors in the intestine? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae causes cholera, a disease characterized by severe watery diarrhea, often referred to as "rice water stools." The pathogenesis of cholera involves the cholera toxin, which plays a critical role in the disease process.

 

Upon ingestion of contaminated food or water, Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin in the intestinal lumen. The cholera toxin (2 subunits – A & B) does not enter the intestinal cells directly; instead, it binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of the intestinal epithelial cells. This binding facilitates the entry of the toxin into the cells.

 

Once inside the cell, the cholera toxin activates the enzyme adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP levels cause the inhibition of sodium absorption and an increase in chloride and water secretion into the intestinal lumen. This results in the characteristic watery diarrhea of cholera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. GM3: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Option D. GM4: This ganglioside receptor is not involved in the binding of cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholera toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP and resulting in watery diarrhea.

questions.text: Most common virus implicated in severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corona Virus

 

Explanation:

 

Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is caused by a coronavirus, specifically the SARS-CoV. This virus led to a significant outbreak of respiratory illness beginning in 2002-2003, originating from Southern China and Hong Kong. Coronaviruses are known to cause respiratory tract infections in humans, and SARS-CoV was a notable example due to its high transmissibility and severe impact on global health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Influenza virus: Causes seasonal flu and is not associated with SARS.

 

Option C. Picorna virus: Includes enteroviruses and rhinoviruses, not associated with SARS.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Causes diseases such as herpes simplex and varicella-zoster, not associated with SARS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SARS is caused by a coronavirus, specifically SARS-CoV.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella/ Salmonella.

 

Enrichment media:

 

It is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow. Common examples include:

 

  • Tetrathionate broth - It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.
  • Selenite F broth - used for dysentery causing bacteria.
  • Alkaline peptone water (Option-B) - used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of anaerobic bacteria, not typically involved in cases of dysentery.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: This is used for the enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly in cases suspected of cholera, which typically presents with watery diarrhea rather than bloody stools.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: It is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

 

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

questions.text:
Which of the following disinfection methods have Non-sporicidal activity but are still useful in healthcare settings? [Twisted PYQ]

  1. Alcohols
  2. Chlorines
  3. Phenols
  4. Quaternary Ammonium compounds
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation: 

 

According to the table, none of these disinfectants possess sporicidal activity, but each has specific healthcare applications:

 

1. Alcohols:

  • Wide microbicidal activity but non-sporicidal
  • Used for hand disinfection and endoscopes
  • Advantage: Non-staining
  • Disadvantage: Flammable

2. Chlorines:

  • Wide microbicidal activity, non-sporicidal
  • Used as surface disinfectant and for cleaning blood/body fluid spills
  • Advantage: Low cost, fast-acting
  • Disadvantage: Corrosive to metal

3. Phenols:

  • Wide microbicidal activity, non-sporicidal
  • Used as surface disinfectant
  • Advantage: Easily available, low cost
  • Disadvantage: Irritant to skin, causes depigmentation

4. Quaternary Ammonium compounds:

  • Microbicidal (spares M. tuberculosis), not sporicidal
  • Used as surface disinfectant for non-critical items
  • Advantage: Less irritant, good detergent property
  • Disadvantage: Can cause occupational asthma

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand that while these disinfectants lack sporicidal activity, they are still valuable in healthcare settings for specific applications. The choice of disinfectant should be based on the required level of disinfection, compatibility with materials, and safety considerations.

questions.text: A traveler consumed oysters. He later presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The organism seen on microscopy exhibited Kanagawa phenomenon. The likely causative organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a salt-loving organism commonly associated with seafood consumption, particularly raw or undercooked oysters. It can cause gastroenteritis characterized by symptoms like watery or bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The Kanagawa phenomenon, which is the hemolysis of human red blood cells on a special medium, is specifically linked with Vibrio parahaemolyticus, further confirming its presence in this case. This bacterium's name also hints at its association with blood ("hemolyticus"), which aligns with the symptoms of bloody diarrhea seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism typically causes food poisoning with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, but it is not associated with bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not specifically related to seafood.

 

Option B. Salmonella typhi: This organism causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and constipation or diarrhea, but not typically bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not linked with seafood consumption or being salt-loving.

 

Option D. Vibrio cholera: While Vibrio cholera is associated with severe watery diarrhea, it does not cause bloody diarrhea or present with the Kanagawa phenomenon. Vibrio cholera also differs from Vibrio parahaemolyticus in its clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is the likely cause of gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea following the consumption of oysters, and it exhibits the Kanagawa phenomenon on microscopy.

questions.text: GeneXpert detects mutations in which of the following genes? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) rроB

 

GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic tool widely used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin. It identifies mutations in the rpoB gene, which encodes the beta subunit of RNA polymerase. These mutations are responsible for rifampicin resistance, a critical marker for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

rpoB: The target gene for rifampicin resistance detection by GeneXpert. Mutations here confer rifampicin resistance

 

WHO strongly recommends Xpert assay for the diagnosis of TB and multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB in patients with HIV infection (WHO 2013).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. inhA: The inhA gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid and ethionamide. However, GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option C. katG: The katG gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid, another key TB drug. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option D. pncA: The pncA gene is associated with resistance to pyrazinamide. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gene(s) involved in anti-tuberculosis drug resistance –

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells
The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

 

MHC Class II molecules are specifically involved in presenting exogenous antigens, ( antigens foreign to the body eg antigens of bacteria, viruses etc)  not endogenous ( self-antigens). These exogenous antigens are typically derived from organisms outside the cell, such as bacteria or viruses that have been ingested by the cell via phagocytosis or endocytosis. MHC Class II then presents peptides from these processed antigens to CD4+ T cells, triggering an immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells: True, which is a key component of the immune response modulation.

 

Option B. The action of MHC II occurs via the endocytic pathway: True, this pathway involves the processing of phagocytosed material.

 

Option D. MHC II is present on antigen-presenting cells: True, which is essential for initiating the immune response by interacting with CD4+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Bio-film confer resistance to antibiotics by all except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adherence

 

Adherence is a mechanism of bacteria to attach to host cell for penetration. It is not a mechanism of resistance.

 

Mechanisms of biofilm-mediated resistance to antibiotics:

 

  • Mechanical barrier: The lipopolysaccharide biofilms prevent entry of water-soluble drugs.
  • Efflux pumps: These pumps on the biofilms actively excrete drug out.
  • Slow metabolism: Decreased oxygen and nutrients passage through the biofilms slows down the metabolism of bacteria.
  • Anaerobic pathway: Because of the above reason bacteria follow anaerobic metabolism.
  • Persisters: Some bacteria undergo phenotypic modification into dormant, spore-like structure and survive antibiotic insult. These are called as persisters which are activated later.
  • Enzymatic inactivation of drugs by biofilms
  • Genetic adaptation to antibiotic insults
  • Quorum sensing: It is cell to cell signaling among the bacteria to coordinate among themselves for contribution in biofilm synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical barrier: Correct. Biofilms provide a physical barrier that prevents the entry of antibiotics.

 

Option B. Increased excretion of antibiotics: Correct. Efflux pumps in biofilms actively expel antibiotics, reducing their intracellular concentration.

 

Option C. Slow metabolism: Correct. The slow metabolic rate within biofilms makes bacteria less susceptible to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biofilms confer resistance to antibiotics through mechanisms such as mechanical barriers, efflux pumps, slow metabolism, and the presence of persisters. Adherence, while important for colonization, does not contribute directly to antibiotic resistance within biofilms.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.

 

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. malariae: Causes quartan malaria with a longer incubation period and typically presents with band-form trophozoites across the red cells, distinct from the forms seen in P. falciparum.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Known for causing tertian malaria with similar clinical presentations to P. vivax, including the presence of Schüffner's dots and slightly enlarged and ovale-shaped erythrocytes.

 

Option D. P. vivax: Also causes tertian malaria, characterized by Schüffner's stippling in erythrocytes, larger ring forms than P. falciparum, and less severe disease outcomes compared to P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identification of P. falciparum through the presence of distinctive ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral smear is crucial for rapid initiation of appropriate antimalarial therapy, particularly in endemic regions. Early treatment is vital to prevent severe complications and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

The above picture is showing the structure of fungal cell wall most likely of Aspergillus fumigatus.

 

Fungal cell wall components - The fungal cell wall contains a cell membrane with various membrane proteins, a protective layer of chitin (yellow) as well as glucans (mostly beta) and mannoproteins on its surface. Different fungal cell walls contain different glucans. For example, the cell wall of A. fumigatus contains β-1,3- and β-1,4-glucan, and α-1,3-glucan, while C. albicans contains β-1,3- and β-1,6-glucan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis cell wall structure has three major cell wall features, including peptidoglycan, arabinogalactan and mycolic acid.

 

 

Option C. Mycoplasma pneumonia is bound by a trilaminar membrane that contains sterols. Cell wall is absent.

 

 

Option D. Recently, Rhinosporidium seeberi has been considered a fungus, but it was originally thought to be a protozoan parasite. Its morphologic characteristics resemble those of Coccidioides immitis: both organisms have mature stages that consist of large, thick-walled spherical structures containing smaller daughter cells (endospores). In addition, R. seeberi is visualized with fungal stains such as methenamine silver and periodic acid-Schiff, as well as mucicarmine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fungal cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus contains β-glucans, chitin, and mannoproteins.

questions.text: Which of the following infection presents with mucus in stools and abdominal pain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba

 

Stools with mucus and abdominal pain are seen in infection due to Entamoeba.

 

Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:

 

  • Dysentery accompanied by lower abdominal discomfort and flatulence. Stools usually have blood and mucus.
  • Chronic amebiasis presents with low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.
  • A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giardia: Is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence. BUT does not release mucus in stool.

 

Option C. Campylobacter: Presents with fever, pain and watery diarrhea. Stool contains leucocytes and blood.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcal food poisoning is toxin-mediated and presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica infection presents with dysentery, characterized by stools containing mucus and blood, along with abdominal pain.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

The given clinical scenario of rice-water stools is suggestive of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by the organism acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors.

 

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications.

 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea.

 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludes toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells.

 

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

 

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Medical management includes erythromycin or azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2 ganglioside receptor: Not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While it is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Option D. Cerebroganglioside: Also not a receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that cholera toxin acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors is crucial for grasping the pathophysiological basis of cholera. This interaction triggers a cascade of events leading to the massive, life-threatening secretory diarrhea that characterizes the disease. Proper hydration and antibiotics like erythromycin are key to treatment.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is presenting with a mucous discharge involving his orbital cavity was found to be spreading from nasal cavity with. Blackish discoloration what is the organism responsible? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucormycosis

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of mucormycosis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic invasive fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, including species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. This infection is particularly dangerous for immunocompromised individuals, such as those with diabetes, especially if it is poorly controlled.

 

Key characteristics of Mucormycosis:

 

  • Blackish discoloration of affected tissues
  • Involvement of the nasal cavity and orbital region
  • Rapid progression
  • High mortality rate if not treated promptly

 

Risk factors:

 

  • Diabetes (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
  • Immunocompromised states (e.g., neutropenia, organ transplantation, hematologic malignancies)
  • Prolonged corticosteroid use

 

Treatment:

 

  • The drug of choice (DOC) for mucormycosis is Amphotericin B.
  • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue is often necessary.
  • Control of underlying conditions (e.g., diabetes) is critical to improving outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: Incorrect. Histoplasmosis is typically caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a fungus that primarily affects the lungs. It does not usually present with blackish discoloration or involve the orbital cavity.

 

Option C. Aspergillosis: Incorrect. Aspergillosis, caused by Aspergillus species, can affect the sinuses and lungs but is less likely to cause the extensive blackish necrosis seen in mucormycosis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus species are bacteria that can cause various infections but do not present with the black necrotic tissue characteristic of mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis, especially in diabetic patients, can lead to black necrotic lesions and rapid spread from the nasal cavity to the orbital region. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with Amphotericin B and surgical debridement are essential.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

A microscopic agglutination test is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Leptospira interrogans is a spirochete with hook-shaped ends found in water contaminated with animal urine, causes Leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis - Flulike symptoms, myalgias (classically of calves), jaundice, photophobia with conjunctival suffusion (erythema without exudate)

 

 

Weil disease (icterohemorrhagic leptospirosis) - severe form with jaundice and azotemia from liver and kidney dysfunction, fever, hemorrhage, and anemia.

 

Laboratory tests - Leptospirae can be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence.

 

Serotype-specific tests - Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)

 

  • Rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospirae - specific IgM antibodies in human sera.

 

Treatment - Penicillin or IV ceftriaxone

 

  • Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. Presents as stepwise increase in fever, abdominal pain, and constipation.

 

Option C. Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test used to diagnose rickettsial infections. Presents as fever, rash, and headache.

 

Option D. Paul-Bunnell test, aka the Monospot test, used to detect heterophile antibodies in case of infectious mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).Presents as fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The microscopic agglutination test is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in symptomatic individuals, especially those exposed to potentially contaminated water environments. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing severe complications like Weil's disease.

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. It is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, commonly known as "rose gardener's disease." This fungal infection occurs when the fungus, which lives in soil, plants, and decaying vegetation, enters the skin through small cuts or punctures. The infection usually starts as a small nodule at the site of entry and can spread along lymphatic channels, causing nodular lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans: This fungus is typically associated with systemic infections, particularly cryptococcal meningitis, in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS. It is not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: This is a systemic mycotic agent that causes histoplasmosis, a respiratory infection that can disseminate in immunocompromised individuals. It is not a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option D. Talaromyces marneffei: Formerly known as Penicillium marneffei, this fungus causes systemic mycoses, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS. It is endemic in Southeast Asia and not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The term systemic mycoses is used here to refer to infections caused by organisms in the following genera: Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Histoplasma, and Cryptococcus.

choices.text: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria

questions.text: Bacterial transduction occurs by? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacteriophage

 

Transduction is a mechanism of genetic exchange in bacteria where DNA is transferred from one bacterium to another via a bacteriophage, a type of virus that infects bacteria. This process involves a phage accidentally incorporating bacterial DNA during the assembly phase within a previously infected host cell. When this phage infects another bacterium, it can introduce the previously acquired bacterial DNA into the new host's genome, facilitating genetic exchange.

 

Other methods of exchange of genetic material are:

 

  • Transformation involves the uptake of genetic material from the environment, which is released by other bacteria.
  • Conjugation is the direct transfer of DNA from one bacterial cell to another bacterial cell through a sex pilus or bridge. The transferred DNA is a plasmid, a circle of DNA that is distinct from the main bacterial chromosome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmids: Incorrect, as plasmids are involved in conjugation, not transduction. They are small, circular DNA molecules within bacteria that can replicate independently of chromosomal DNA.

 

Option B. Sex pili: Incorrect, sex pili are involved in conjugation, where they facilitate the direct transfer of DNA between bacterial cells.

 

Option D. Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria: Incorrect, this describes transformation, where bacteria take up DNA from their environment, not through a virus-mediated process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transduction facilitated by bacteriophages represents a crucial mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria, contributing to genetic diversity and the spread of traits such as antibiotic resistance among bacterial populations.

questions.text: A 65-year-old PLHIV patient came with cough, fever, and pneumonia. Biopsy shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV

 

In the biopsy image, the characteristic feature to note is the presence of inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and the cytoplasm of the cell, giving an appearance often described as "owl eye." This is a hallmark of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV can cause severe infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as patients living with HIV (PLHIV). The virus leads to the formation of large cells with nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella: Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause pneumonia, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not produce the distinctive "owl eye" inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

 

Option C. EBV: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is known for causing infectious mononucleosis and is associated with various lymphoproliferative disorders, but there is no inclusion bodies in the cells.

 

Option D. HSV2: Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2) can cause various infections, including pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, but it does not produce the specific "owl eye" inclusions seen in CMV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of "owl eye" inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of cells in a biopsy is indicative of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those living with HIV.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Somatic hypermutation

 

Affinity maturation is a process that occurs in B cells during an immune response, leading to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for their antigen. This process is primarily driven by somatic hypermutation (SHM).

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM): This involves the introduction of point mutations at a high rate in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin (Ig) genes in activated B cells. These mutations occur in the DNA encoding the variable regions of both heavy and light chains of the antibody molecule.
  • Selection for High Affinity: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively expanded. Those with mutations that increase the affinity of the antibody for its antigen are positively selected and proliferate, whereas B cells with lower affinity or non-functional antibodies are eliminated.
  • Result: This process leads to the production of high-affinity antibodies over time, enhancing the effectiveness of the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isotype Switching: Also known as class switch recombination, this process changes the antibody isotype (e.g., from IgM to IgG) but does not directly affect the antigen-binding affinity.

 

Option C. mRNA Splicing: This process involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA to produce mature mRNA, but it is not involved in affinity maturation.

 

Option D. VDJ Rearrangement: This process generates the initial diversity of the antigen receptor repertoire by recombining variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments. It occurs before exposure to antigen and does not contribute to the increased affinity seen in affinity maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Affinity maturation, which results in the production of high-affinity antibodies, is primarily due to somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled with selective survival and proliferation of B cells producing high-affinity antibodies.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhizopus

 

Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect, although Candida is a common opportunistic pathogen, it is more frequently associated with mucocutaneous and systemic infections rather than orbital cellulitis.

 

Option C. Aspergillus: Incorrect, Aspergillus can cause a variety of infections including orbital cellulitis, but it is not the most common cause in the context of diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Option D. Trichophyton: Incorrect, Trichophyton primarily causes skin infections such as ringworm and athlete's foot, and is not typically associated with orbital cellulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhizopus is the predominant fungal pathogen linked with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, underscoring the critical need for prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment in such high-risk groups to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: Desert rheumatism is caused by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coccidioides immitis


Desert rheumatism, also known as Valley fever or California fever, is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis. This fungus is commonly found in desert regions, such as the southwestern United States, including California and Arizona. The disease is contracted by inhaling airborne fungal spores, which can cause symptoms ranging from mild flu-like conditions to severe pulmonary or disseminated infections. The mnemonic "Desert, Valley, Cali" helps remember the association with desert rheumatism, Valley fever, and California fever, all linked to Coccidioides immitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: This condition is caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, which is commonly found in bird and bat droppings, particularly in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. It does not cause desert rheumatism.

 

Option C. Mucormycosis: This is an infection caused by molds from the Mucorales order, which typically affects immunocompromised individuals. It is not associated with desert rheumatism.

 

Option D. Paracoccidioidomycosis: This disease is caused by the fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and occurs predominantly in South America. It is unrelated to desert rheumatism.

 

Educational Objective:


Desert rheumatism (Valley fever or California fever) is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis.

questions.text: The organism with following life cycle is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The given life cycle is of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Infective form - Filariform larvae

 

Natural host – Man

 

Mode of infection – penetration of skin by filariform larvae and autoinfection


 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that infects humans through skin penetration by its larvae.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides is a roundworm that infects humans through ingestion of contaminated food or water.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis is a pinworm that infects humans through ingestion of its eggs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis involves skin penetration by filariform larvae and autoinfection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient had a tooth extraction three days back. He now presents with a mass in the submandibular region which is otherwise asymptomatic. There is no ulcer on the oral mucosa. On drainage of the discharge, it was foul-smelling with a lot of yellow granules. They showed gram-positive filamentous rods on grams staining. What is the most likely implicated pathogen? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Actinomycetes israelli

 

This clinical history is suggestive of cervicofacial actinomycosis which is caused by Actinomyces israeli.

 

Actinomyces are non-sporeforming, filamentous, and facultative anaerobes. They are normal constituents of the oral flora within gingival crevices and tonsillar crypts and are particularly prevalent in periodontal pockets, dental plaques, and on carious teeth.

 

Actinomyces bacteria cannot penetrate healthy tissue, and mucosal breakdown is a prerequisite for infection. Poor dental hygiene, caries, oral trauma, dental extraction, and an immunocompromised status are considered to be important antecedents.

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis or lumpy jaw is the most frequent clinical form of actinomycosis, and “lumpy jaw syndrome”, which is associated with odontogenic infection, is the most common clinical manifestation.

 

It presents as a painless or occasionally painful soft-tissue swelling involving the submandibular or perimandibular region; over time, multiple sinuses drain pus containing sulfur granules; tendency to remit and recur. There is reddish or bluish discoloration of the skin overlying the lesion, chewing difficulties (i.e., with involvement of mastication muscles) are also seen.

 

Other types -

 

  • Thoracic actinomycosis- 
    • History of aspiration (Risk factors include seizure disorder, alcoholism, and poor dental hygiene.)
    • Dry or productive cough, occasionally blood-streaked sputum, shortness of breath, chest pain pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- 
    • History of abdominal surgery, perforated viscus, mesenteric vascular insufficiency, or ingestion of foreign bodies (e.g., fish or chicken bones)
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- 
    • History of IUCD
    • Lower abdominal discomfort, abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge

 

A Gram-stained smear of the specimen may demonstrate the presence of beaded, branched, gram-positive filamentous rods, with a sun ray appearance suggesting the diagnosis of actinomycosis.

 

 

Culture - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth. On solid media, A. israeli produces spidery colonies.

 

Treatment - Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin’s such as amoxicillin are now popular. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromoblastomycosis: This is a chronic fungal infection characterized by verrucous skin lesions, typically affecting the lower extremities. It does not present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: This is a severe fungal infection caused by fungi in the order Mucorales. It usually affects immunocompromised individuals and presents with rhino-orbital-cerebral or pulmonary infections, not typically associated with submandibular masses and sulfur granules.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, primarily affecting the lungs and sometimes disseminating in immunocompromised individuals. It does not typically present with the described symptoms and findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervicofacial actinomycosis, commonly caused by Actinomyces israelii, presents with submandibular masses, often after dental procedures, with foul-smelling discharge containing yellow sulfur granules. Gram staining reveals gram-positive filamentous rods, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunochromatography

 

The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

 

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses enzyme-labeled antibodies and an enzymatic reaction to produce a detectable signal, usually a color change, and typically requires more time and equipment to perform.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Involves the use of fluorescent-labeled antibodies to detect specific antigens or antibodies in a sample, requiring specialized equipment to visualize fluorescence.

 

Option D. Chemiluminescence: Relies on a chemical reaction that produces light to detect antigens or antibodies, also requiring specialized equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunochromatographic tests, such as the HbsAg card test, provide a rapid, user-friendly, and effective means of testing for certain antigens or antibodies directly at the point of care. Their simplicity and speed make them invaluable tools in clinical settings, especially where quick decision-making is crucial.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (mucor and Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

Fungal cell wall:

 

  • Fungal cell walls are rigid and contain complex polysaccharides called chitin (adds structural strength) and glucans.
  • Ergosterol is the steroid molecule in the cell membranes that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.

 

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

 

G-test: Detects a-3 glucan. Used in diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Tests for beta-d-glucan: Raised levels are seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins found in the fungal cell wall, contributing to its structure and function.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi, including those causing mucormycosis. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of fungal cell membranes, not the cell wall. It replaces cholesterol found in animal cell membranes and is essential for maintaining membrane integrity and function in fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text: A patient's plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Virus

 

Interferon-beta (IFN-β) is a type I interferon, which is predominantly secreted in response to viral infections. Interferons are proteins that play a crucial role in the immune response to pathogens, particularly viruses. They help inhibit viral replication within host cells and activate immune cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria: Bacterial infections are primarily associated with pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1, TNF-α, and IL-6, rather than type I interferons.

 

Option C. Fungi: Fungal infections do not typically induce high levels of interferon-beta.

 

Option D. Mycoplasm: Mycoplasma infections are more likely to induce other immune responses rather than a significant increase in interferon-beta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of interferons:

questions.text: A truck driver is presenting with a painless ulcer with firm base, what is the next investigation you will prefer to do?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscopy for spirochetes

 

The presentation of a painless ulcer with a firm base is highly suggestive of a syphilitic chancre, which is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. The most appropriate next investigation for diagnosing syphilis in this context is dark field microscopy.

 

 

Dark Field Microscopy:

 

  • It is used to directly visualize Treponema pallidum in fluid from the ulcer.
  • This method allows the detection of the characteristic motility of spirochetes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gram staining: Incorrect. Treponema pallidum is not effectively visualized with Gram staining due to its thin and delicate structure.

 

Option C. Tzanck smear for giant cells: Incorrect. Tzanck smear is used for diagnosing viral infections like herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which present with different clinical features such as painful vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Cell line culture: Incorrect. Cell culture is not routinely used for diagnosing syphilis and is more applicable for viral pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycetoma

 

The most likely diagnosis here is Mycetoma which is caused by Eumycetoma.

 

Mycetoma is an uncommon chronic granulomatous infective disease of the skin/dermis and subcutaneous tissues. “Madura Foot” or “Maduramycosis,” it is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by the filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

 

It is characterized by a triad of tumefaction, draining sinuses and the presence of colonial grains in the exudates. It is seen commonly in people who walk barefoot. Eumycetoma is more common in Northern India, while Actinomycetoma is more common in Southern India.

 

The two main groups of mycetoma are the Actinomycotic and Eumycotic groups. Actinomycetoma is caused by a group of filamentous bacteria which include Nocardia and Streptomyces species. The Nocardia species include Nocardia asteroids, Nocardia braziliensis and Nocardia caviae. The Streptomyces species include Streptomyces madurae, Streptomyces pelletieri and Streptomyces somaliensis.

 

The color of the grains found in the discharge is indicative of the species and helps to initiate appropriate treatment.

 

The foot is the most commonly affected and the dorsal aspect of the left foot for unexplained reasons is more affected.

 

The grains are histologically seen as sulfur granules surrounded by neutrophils which lead to a purulent tissue reaction containing fibroblasts. This prevents the antibiotic from acting on the micro-organisms, hence the need for debridement in certain cases.

 

Combined drug therapy is preferred to a single drug therapy to avoid resistance and any residual infection.

 

Surgical debridement, followed by prolonged appropriate antibiotic therapy for several months is required for actinomycetoma while a combination therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (14 mg/kg, twice daily), dapsone (1.5 mg/kg, twice daily) and streptomycin (14 mg/kg) has been used along with Rifampicin for resistant cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or nodule and does not exhibit the characteristic draining sinuses and grains seen in mycetoma.

 

Option C. Nocardia: Nocardia can cause mycetoma (specifically actinomycetoma), but in the context of the broad diagnosis, mycetoma is the more inclusive and accurate term.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, usually presents with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels rather than multiple sinuses and grains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma is characterized by swelling, draining sinuses, and colonial grains in exudates, and is common among individuals who walk barefoot. The diagnosis is supported by clinical presentation, histology, and the color of the grains. Treatment involves surgical debridement and prolonged antibiotic therapy for actinomycetoma or antifungal therapy for eumycetoma.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are typically made from the polysaccharide capsule that surrounds certain bacteria. These vaccines are designed to protect against bacterial infections by inducing immunity against the polysaccharide antigens present in the capsule.

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant vaccine that uses a portion of the hepatitis B virus (HBsAg - hepatitis B surface antigen) produced in yeast cells. This vaccine does not involve a polysaccharide component as the hepatitis B virus does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal: The pneumococcal vaccine is available in both polysaccharide (PPSV23) and conjugate forms (PCV13), targeting the polysaccharide capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Meningococcal: Meningococcal vaccines also include polysaccharide (MPSV4) and conjugate forms (MCV4), aimed at the polysaccharide capsule of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option C. H. influenzae: The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a conjugate vaccine that includes the polysaccharide antigen from the bacterial capsule conjugated to a protein carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

questions.text: A dairy plant reported an outbreak of Q fever. Which pasteurization method most likely failed to prevent this outbreak? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low-temperature holding at 63°C for 30 minutes

 

Explanation: 

 

Coxiella burnetii, the causative organism of Q fever, is notably resistant to standard pasteurization methods. The low-temperature holding method (Holder method) at 63°C for 30 minutes may not completely eliminate C. burnetii, making it the most likely culprit in a Q fever outbreak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flash pasteurization (72°C for 15 seconds): Is effective against C. burnetii

 

Option B. High-temperature short-time (85°C for 1 second) treatment exceeds the thermal death point of C. burnetii

 

Option D. Ultra-high temperature processing (135°C for 1-2 seconds) completely eliminates all viable microorganisms including spores

 

The temperature-time combinations in options A, B, and D are sufficient to kill C. burnetii, while the Holder method (option C) may allow some organisms to survive.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the limitations of different pasteurization methods, particularly regarding the survival of Coxiella burnetii in the Holder method, is crucial for preventing milk-borne diseases and ensuring public health safety.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

questions.text: A patient with HIV develops diarrhea and faecal examination shows Isospora belli. He was treated with cotrimoxazole. Diarrhoea subsided but fever persisted. Bone marrow examination of this patient is shown in the given image below. Which of the following statement is false? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

 

Based on the clinical picture, an HIV positive patient had infection with Isospora belli which was treated with cotrimoxazole. The bone marrow examination showed narrow based budding yeast cells suggestive of infection with Histoplasma capsulatum

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is a thermally dimorphic fungus which exists as a mycelial form at ambient temperatures and grows as small round budding yeast cells at body temperature in mammals.
  • Growth on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 25ºC shows a white to brown colony, cottony mycelium after 2 to 3 weeks.
  • The mold phase is characterized by thin, branching, septate hyphae that produce microconidia and a very distinct spore called a tuberculate macroconidium.
  • Grown at 37ºC shows the budding yeast form. Yeast cells occur within budding yeasts as intracellular fungi.
  • The yeast cell is 2-4 µm in diameter and slightly oval in shape and found exclusively within macrophages.
  • Mode of infection - Inhalation of spores
  • Disseminated infection can occur in immunocompromised patients with reticuloendothelial system being affected the most.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spores are infective form: Correct. Spores of Histoplasma capsulatum are the infective form. They are inhaled into the lungs, where they convert to yeast form and cause infection.
