Option C. It is intracellular budding yeast: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum is an intracellular budding yeast when it infects the host. It is typically found within macrophages.

 

Option D. It can cause systemic disease: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum can cause systemic disease, especially in immunocompromised individuals, affecting the reticuloendothelial system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histoplasma capsulatum, a thermally dimorphic fungus, can grow on Sabouraud dextrose agar, produce infective spores, exist as an intracellular budding yeast in humans, and cause systemic disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.

 

Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic presentation of the severe disease called Wei's syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver.

 

Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative bradycardia ( aka Fagets sign) can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chikungunya: Typically presents with fever, severe joint pain, and rash, not prominently featuring jaundice or hepatic involvement.

 

Option C. Dengue hemorrhagic fever: While this can present with fever and potential liver involvement, the hallmark is severe bleeding and plasma leakage.

 

Option D. Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A: Generally presents with jaundice and neurological symptoms due to liver dysfunction but does not typically include calf pain or conjunctival suffusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of fever, jaundice, muscle pain, and conjunctival suffusion, especially if there is a history of exposure to potentially contaminated water. Recognizing these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxiella burnetii

 

Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii is typically made through serology for specific antibodies rather than Giemsa staining.

 

Giemsa stain is a differential stain which is made up of a combination of reagents (Azure, Methylene blue, and Eosin dye) used widely in cytogenetics and histopathology for the diagnosis of:

 

  • Malaria, spirochetes and other blood parasites
  • Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion bodies
  • Borrelia spp
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Histoplasma spp
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci cysts
  • Bartonella henselae
  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Talaromyces marneffei (formerly called Penicillium marneffei)

 

In parasitology to detect intraerythrocytic (plasmodia, babesiae) and exoerythrocytic (trypanosomes, microfilaria) parasites. It is also used for the detection of intracellular amastigotes of Leishmania species or Trypanosoma cruzi. Giemsa stain is also used for the laboratory diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toxoplasma gondii: Giemsa stain is used for the laboratory diagnosis of toxoplasmosis, which involves the detection of intracellular organisms.

 

Option C. Bartonella henselae: Giemsa stain can be used to identify Bartonella henselae, particularly in blood smears.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Giemsa stain is effective in diagnosing infections caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis by identifying the morulae within white blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxiella burnetii cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. Serology for specific antibodies is the method used for its diagnosis. Giemsa stain is a versatile stain used to diagnose a variety of blood parasites and intracellular pathogen.

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene

 

Resistance to ganciclovir (GCV) most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene.

 

Viral UL97 kinase and UL54 DNA polymerase gene mutations are well-documented mechanisms of resistance to current antivirals. The UL97 kinase normally phosphorylates serine and threonine residues of various cellular and viral proteins, and is required for efficient CMV replication. This kinase also effects the initial phosphorylation of GCV that is required for antiviral activity, and UL97 mutations that impair this phosphorylation are the preferred mechanism of GCV resistance.

 

UL54 mutations can confer resistance to all current drugs and may emerge after prolonged GCV therapy to increase the level of resistance conferred by a pre-existing UL97 mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the host.

 

Option C: CMV infection is mostly subclinical. In immunocompromised individuals, CMV can cause various manifestations, including retinitis, colitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis, but watery diarrhea is not the most common manifestation.

 

Option D: UL54 mutations can confer resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir, and foscamet. These mutations affect the viral DNA polymerase, leading to cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CMV is ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. This gene is responsible for the initial phosphorylation of ganciclovir, and mutations here can prevent the drug's activation, leading to resistance. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, and UL54 mutations can confer cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs, including foscarnet. CMV infections are mostly subclinical, and the common manifestations in immunocompromised patients are not typically watery diarrhea.

questions.text: Choose the egg belonging to the following parasite from the column B? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

The above worm is Enterobius vermicularis

 

Adults are short, white, fusiform worms with pointed ends, looking like bits of white thread. The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like curricular expansions (cervical alae), which are transversely striated. as seen in the image provided in the question. The esophagus has a double bulb structure, a feature unique to this worm.

 

 

The egg is colorless and not bile-stained. It floats in saturated salt solution. It has a characteristic shape, being elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other (planoconvex), measuring 50-60 μm by 20-30 μm. The eggshell is double-layered and relatively thick, though transparent. The outer albuminous layer makes the eggs stick to each other and to clothing and other objects. The egg contains a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo, which is fully formed, but becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited on the skin. Under cool moist conditions, the egg remains viable for about 2 weeks.

 

 

The correctly matched egg for the given parasite - Enterobius vermicularis is 3

 

Other choices:
 

Option A: Egg of Hymenolepsis nana
 

Option B: Egg of Tenia species 
 

Option D: Fertilized egg of ascaris
 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis eggs are elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other, with a double-layered, thick, transparent shell and contain a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo.

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans.

 

Germ tube test is a screening test for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. Candida dubliniensis can also form germ tubes and Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that closely resemble germ tubes.

 

Germ tube formation was first reported by Reynolds and Braude and hence the germ tube test is also known as Reynolds-Braude phenomenon.

 

Buds and pseudo-hyphae can be distinguished from germ tubes by the constricted attachment at the point of origin. Germ tubes don’t show constriction at the point of origin.

 

Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis produce short, slender, tube-like structures called germ tubes.

 

The formation of germ tubes is associated with increased synthesis of protein and ribonucleic acid. Various media like fetal bovine serum may be used as a substitute for human pooled serum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida glabrata: Candida glabrata does not produce germ tubes. It forms small, round yeast cells.

 

Option C. Candida parapsilosis: Candida parapsilosis does not produce germ tubes. It forms pseudohyphae and yeast cells.

 

Option D. Candida tropicalis: Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that resemble germ tubes, but they show constriction at the point of origin. This is a distinguishing feature from the true germ tubes of Candida albicans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The germ tube test is used for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. It detects the formation of germ tubes, which are characteristic of Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis but not other Candida species. Germ tubes are short, slender, tube-like structures without constriction at their point of origin, differentiating them from pseudohyphae.

questions.text:
In a transplant recipient with suspected fungal infection, which test combination would be most appropriate for diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)

 

  1. Galactomannan assay
  2. Beta-D-glucan test
  3. Calcofluor white stain
  4. India ink preparation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 & 3 only

 

Explanation: 

 

In transplant recipients, multiple fungal infections can coexist, necessitating a combination of diagnostic tests:

 

1. Galactomannan assay specifically detects invasive aspergillosis

 

2. Beta-D-glucan is a pan-fungal marker present in most fungal cell walls except Mucorales and Cryptococcus

 

3. Calcofluor white is a fluorescent stain that binds to chitin in fungal cell walls, allowing visualization of most fungi

 

4. India ink is specifically used for Cryptococcus detection and is less relevant in initial screening of transplant recipients where Aspergillus and Candida are more common pathogens.

 

Option A (1 & 2) misses the important direct microscopic examination capability of calcofluor white

 

Option B (2 & 3) excludes galactomannan, which is crucial for early detection of invasive aspergillosis

 

Option D (all) includes India ink, which has limited utility as an initial screening tool in transplant recipients

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the complementary nature of different fungal diagnostic tests and their appropriate combination for comprehensive diagnosis in immunocompromised patients, particularly transplant recipients.

questions.text: A patient who has a pet dog, came with a complaint of hypochondrial pain. The radiological imaging showed cyst within the liver. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The key points that indicate Echinococcus granulosus as the causative organism are:

 

  1. The patient has a pet dog, which is the definitive host for Echinococcus granulosus (also known as the dog tapeworm).
  2. The patient presented with hypochondrial pain, which could be caused by the formation of cyst in the liver.
  3. Radiological imaging revealed a cyst within the liver, which is characteristic of Echinococcus granulosus infection.

 

Echinococcus granulosus is a cestode (tapeworm) parasite that causes hydatid cyst disease, primarily affecting the liver and lungs. The life cycle involves dogs (or other canids like wolves and foxes) as the definitive hosts, where the adult tapeworm resides in the intestine. The eggs are passed in the feces of these definitive hosts and can contaminate food or water sources.

 

Humans become accidental intermediate hosts by ingesting these eggs. Once ingested, the eggs hatch in the human intestine, and the larvae migrate to various organs, most commonly the liver (70-80% of cases), where they develop into unilocular hydatid cyst.

 

 

 

Life cycle

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This is a protozoan parasite that causes amebic liver abscesses, not multilocular cysts. It is not transmitted by dogs and does not form characteristic multilocular cysts.

 

Option C. Taenia solium: Also known as the pork tapeworm, this organism can cause cysticercosis, where cysts form in muscle, brain, and other tissues, but it's not primarily known for liver cysts.

 

Option D. Diphyllobothrium latum: This is a fish tapeworm that primarily leads to vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia, not liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Echinococcus granulosus, also known as the dog tapeworm, can cause hydatid cyst disease in humans, with multilocular cysts commonly found in the liver. Owning a pet dog and ingesting food or water contaminated with dog feces containing the parasite's eggs are risk factors for acquiring this infection.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

 

The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy.

 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallium. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

 

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

 

  • Treponemes generally are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electron microscope: While capable of revealing detailed structures of microorganisms, it is not typically used in clinical settings for diagnosing infections due to its complexity and cost.

 

Option C. Light microscope: Standard light microscopy, typically used with staining techniques, does not easily allow for the visualization of live motility or very thin bacteria like Treponema pallidum.

 

Option D. Fluorescent microscope: Although it can be used to detect specific pathogens if fluorescent-tagged antibodies are available, it is not the standard method for observing motility or diagnosing syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is essential for observing the motility of Treponema pallidum directly from lesions such as a syphilitic chancre. This diagnostic tool is critical in early stages of syphilis when direct visualization of the pathogen can confirm infection before serological tests become positive.

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Filariasis

 

Transmission assessment survey is carried out for filariasis.

 

Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is targeted for global elimination through treatment of entire at-risk populations with repeated annual mass drug administration (MDA). Essential for program success is defining and confirming the appropriate endpoint for MDA when transmission is presumed to have reached a level low enough that it cannot be sustained even in the absence of drug intervention. Guidelines advanced by WHO call for a transmission assessment survey (TAS) to determine if MDA can be stopped within an LF evaluation unit (EU) after at least five effective rounds of annual treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P. vivax: Transmission assessment surveys are not typically used for evaluating the transmission of Plasmodium vivax, which causes malaria.

 

Option B. P. falciparum: Transmission assessment surveys are not typically used for evaluating the transmission of Plasmodium falciparum, another cause of malaria.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Transmission assessment surveys are not used for Leishmania species, which cause leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) are essential tools used to evaluate the success of mass drug administration programs for lymphatic filariasis and determine if the transmission levels are low enough to discontinue these programs.

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly male patient who received a kidney transplant a decade ago is presently under immunosuppressive treatment. He reports experiencing a persistent cough and shortness of breath over the past week. Microscopic examination of his sputum reveals the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the probable diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive candidiasis

 

  • The presented clinical scenario, coupled with the microscopy revealing gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae, strongly indicates the presence of invasive candidiasis.
  • Candida albicans has a unique ability to transform frequently between three phenotypic forms in the tissue: yeast, pseudohyphae, true hyphae. This property helps it to evade host defense system.
  • Invasive candidiasis results from hematogenous or local spread of the fungi.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor shows, broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching.

 

Option B. Aspergillus shows septate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive candidiasis is characterized by the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae in tissue or clinical specimens, especially in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Which protozoan parasite's lifecycle is characterized by direct human-to-human transmission through feco-oral route with no involvement of definitive animal host? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cryptosporidium

 

Cryptosporidium has a direct lifecycle with no requirement for an intermediate host or vector. 

 

The key aspects include:

  • Infected humans shed sporulated oocysts in feces that are immediately infectious
  • Direct transmission occurs through fecal-oral route
  • Autoinfection is possible, leading to chronic infections
  • No animal definitive host is required to complete the lifecycle

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma gondii: Requires cats as definitive hosts. Has a complex lifecycle involving intermediate hosts and cannot be transmitted directly between humans except congenitally.

 

Option C. Cystoisospora: Though it has a direct lifecycle, humans are the definitive hosts but transmission typically involves environmental maturation of oocysts rather than direct human-to-human spread.

 

Option D. Giardia lamblia: While it has direct transmission, the cysts typically require time in the environment to become infective and zoonotic transmission is common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium has true direct human-to-human transmission · Importance of distinguishing between parasites requiring definitive hosts vs direct transmission · Understanding immediate infectivity of Cryptosporidium oocysts · Recognition of autoinfection in pathogenesis

choices.text: Growth in MacConkey and blood agar but not chocolate agar
Growth in MacConkey and chocolate agar but not blood agar
Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium
Growth in MacConkey, blood, and chocolate agar

questions.text: True regarding H. influenzae growth:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium

 

Option C:

 

Growth in blood and chocolate agar but not MacConkey medium: Correct. H. influenzae grows on chocolate agar, which provides the X and V factors released from lysed blood cells. It can also grow on blood agar if Staphylococcus species are present (satellitism), which provide the necessary V factor. It does not grow on MacConkey agar.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Growth in MacConkey and blood agar but not chocolate agar: H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar as it is a selective medium designed for Gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae has specific growth requirements not met by this medium.

 

Option B. Growth in MacConkey and chocolate agar but not blood agar: Similar to option A, H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar. It can grow on chocolate agar because it provides the necessary factors (X factor - hemin and V factor - NAD) released from lysed blood cells.

 

Option D. Growth in MacConkey, blood, and chocolate agar: As previously explained, H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Haemophilus influenzae grows on chocolate agar and can grow on blood agar under specific conditions (presence of Staphylococcus species for V factor), but it does not grow on MacConkey agar due to its selective nature against non-coliform bacteria.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 2/e p361
